Graphical abstract In this study, a systematic investigation on the degradation of phenacetin (PNT) by magnetic spinel ferrite (including MnFe2O4 and NiFe2O4) via catalytic ozonation was carried out. The structural and surface property of the catalyst, the performance and mineralization during PNT degradation, and •OH/H2O2 identification were studied. The precursors of the catalyst, i.e. MnFe2(OH)8 and NiFe2(OH)8, showed certain magnetic properties and a superior catalytic activity for ozonation enhancement than spinel ferrites. Spinel ferrites containing manganese initiate an ozone mass transfer into the solution, where the critical intermediate (H2O2) is generated. The manganese ferrite spinel triggers H2O2 decomposition in the presence of ozone and generates •OH for the mineralization of PNT and its intermediates. Spinel ferrites involved nickel catalyzed ozone decomposition and generate H2O2 and •OH. All catalysts showed a weak heavy metal leaching, which suggests that the heterogeneous reaction dominates the catalytic reaction and the resultant effluent is safe for the aqueous environment. The magnetic variation of catalysts involving nickel is insignificant, suggesting that the catalyst can be reused many times. The fate of the intermediates on spinel oxides surface influenced for the catalytic ozonation process differently. Keywords Hydroxyl radical Magnetic nano-particles Ozonation Peroxide Phenacetin 1 Introduction Magnetic spinel ferrites, with a general formula of MeFe2O4 (Me denotes a divalent metal such as Fe(II), Mn(II), Ni(II), Zn(II), Co(II), and so on), are chemically and thermally stable magnetic materials that have been used in many applications [1–4], such as adsorbents [5–7] and photo-catalysts [8,9] for the removal of toxic substances in water. The high density of surface hydroxyl group (OH) and active elements make spinel ferrites good catalyst in enhancing ozonation process [10–13]. Magnetic particles can be separated from solution using a simple magnetic process, which make it superior to other iron oxides (such as FeOOH [14–16], and Fe3O4 [17,18]). CuFe2O4 [13], NiFe2O4 [11,12] and Bi2CuO4 [19] have been used in catalytic ozonation for the degradation of refractory organic pollutants. The investigated spinel ferrite oxides have been synthesized by co-precipitation/combustion [13,20], sol–gel/hydrothermal [11,12] and sonochemical [19] methods. Despite promising results in catalytic ozonation using spinel ferrite as the catalyst, the development of one efficient catalyst or novelty synthesis method is still a major research aim. However, the release of metal ions during the reaction and accumulation of organic intermediates on the catalyst surface may affect catalyst stability/activity and create a major obstacle for its application. Especially, the understanding of the role of the spinel ferrite surface properties in catalytic reactions and the magnetism variation after recycling still remain unclear. In this study, MnFe2O4 (MFO) and NiFe2O4 (NFO) were used in catalytic ozonation for the degradation of phenacetin (PNT, N-(4-ethoxyphenyl) acetamide), and a non-opioid analgesic and antipyretic agent, that is found frequently in water [21]. Recently, many studies have focused on the removal efficiency of PNT from water by several advanced oxidation processes (AOPs) [22–24]. It is interesting to find that the precursors for synthesizing the catalysts (i.e. MnFe2(OH)8 (MFOH) and NiFe2(OH)8 (NFOH)) also exhibit magnetic properties and display catalytic potential in this study. Therefore, four different catalysts were investigated in detail by comparing their surface properties, magnetic properties and catalytic activities in this study. The magnetism variation after repeated usages and the active metal ions leaching, the role of spinel ferrite surface properties in catalytic ozonation, and the effect of intermediates on the catalytic activity were studied as well. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Chemicals All chemicals and solvents were of analytic reagent grade and high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) grade, respectively, and were used as received without any further purification. Model compound, PNT (>99% purity), was purchased from International Laboratory (USA). Distilled-deionized water (DDW) was generated from a Banstead NANO pure water treatment system (Thermo Fisher Scientific Inc., USA). The resistivity of DDW was 18.2MΩ·cm and was used to prepare all the solutions in this study. Nickel nitrate, manganous nitrate, ferric nitrate and sodium hydroxide were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich Inc. (USA) for the preparation of magnetic nanoparticles. 2.2 Catalyst synthesis and characterization MeFe2O4 was prepared by co-precipitation- calcination method revised from the previous work [25]. The details for the preparation methods and characterization process were provided in Text S1 of Supplementary material (SM). MeFe2(OH)8 was synthesized by co-precipitation method without the calcination. 2.3 Catalytic ozonation reactions The setup of the tested ozonation system consisted of a glass column equipped with gas inlet and outlet. The solution temperature was controlled by the water jacket. Ozone was produced from pure oxygen using the OZAT ozone generator (CFS-1A from Ozonia Ltd.) and bubbled into the bottom of the column with a diffuser at a rate of 1.0mL/min continuously. In this study, all experiments were carried out under a semi-batch mode to simulate the wastewater treatment plant, and the reported concentration was the initial dissolved ozone concentration. The ozone yield was adjusted by changing the voltage of the ozone generator. In general, 100mL pure water was pre-ozonated for 5min (to reach a saturation condition). The catalytic ozonation process was initiated by adding 1mL of PNT stock solution (20.0mM) and catalyst (200mg) simultaneously into the pre-ozonated solution with stirring (400rpm) under ambient temperature that was controlled by the water jacket. The samples were withdrawn at a predetermined time and the reaction was quenched. For PNT/total organic carbon (TOC) determination, the reaction was quenched by sodium thiosulfate (0.1M) and the solution was filtered through a 0.45μm PTFE membrane to ensure the solution was free from catalysts prior to quantification (PNT adsorption by PTFE membrane was found to be insignificant); while for quantification of dissolved ozone concentration, the solution was quenched by indigo and centrifuged to remove the catalyst. The same condition was used for the sole ozonation process (SOP, without catalyst) and PNT adsorption on the catalyst (purging with oxygen only, without ozone). After the tests, the spent catalysts were recovered from the mixture by magnetic field and they were then used directly in the following test without any treatment. All experiments were conducted three times; the average data and error bars are shown in the figures. Solution pH was adjusted by HNO3 and NaOH in all reactions when required. 2.4 Analytical method The concentration of PNT was analyzed using a high performance liquid chromatography (HPLC, Waters Instrument, USA) with a UV detector at the wavelength of 240nm with a Restek pinnacle octylamine column (5μm, 0.46×25cm). The mobile phase was 60% CH3CN and 40% phosphoric acid solution (0.08%). The LC analysis standard deviation (SD) was less than 6.00% and the detection limitation was 0.5μM. TOC was determined by a TOC Analyzer (TOC-5000A, Shimadzu), with a SD of less than 5.40% and a detection limitation of 0.5mg/L. The dissolved ozone concentration was measured colorimetrically by the indigo method [26] and the gas type ozone was measured by the iodometric method. The concentration of H2O2 was determined by measuring the absorbance of the titanium peroxide (TiO2 2+) complex formed from the reaction of TiOSO4 with H2O2 using a Biochrom Libra S12 spectrophotometer at 405nm [27] with SD of less than 4.33% and a detection limitation of 0.01mM. The dissolution of ions during the reaction was analyzed by inductively coupled plasma-atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) with a SD of less than 5.10%. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Structural characteristics of the catalyst The surface texture parameters and N2 adsorption–desorption curve/pore distribution of the tested catalysts are shown in Table 1 and Fig. 1 , respectively. From Fig. 1(A), the specific BET surface area could be obtained. NFOH had the largest surface area (215.73m2/g), while MFO had the lowest surface area (42.51m2/g). In general, the specific surface area of the hydroxides (NFOH and MFOH) was higher than that of the calcined oxides (NFO and MFO); and the oxides containing nickel was larger surface area than that of manganese. The N2 adsorption–desorption curves of four catalysts correspond mainly to the type IV isotherm, indicating that both micro and mesopores exist in the catalysts [28]. A hysteresis loop was visible for NFOH and NFO, but was not for MFOH and MFO. The hysteresis loop suggested the presence of a non-cylindrical-shaped pore in the crude wall [29,30]. The pore distribution of catalysts was shown in Fig. 1(B). The pore type of NFOH/NFO was apparently different from that of MFOH/MFO, and the pore volume of the former was higher than the latter. The hydroxides showed two focused peaks of pore diameter at 3.0–5.0nm and 15.0–90.0nm. After the calcination, the pore diameter distribution transferred to one focused peak at 3.0–15.0nm. The pore diameter in NFO or MFO was wider than that in NFOH or MFOH, and the mesopores in NFO and MFO became more significant. The surface acidity and alkalinity were determined by the temperature-programmed desorption of ammonia (NH3-TPD, Fig. 2(A)) and carbon dioxide (CO2-TPD, Fig. 2(B)), respectively. Two NH3 desorption peaks were detected in the tested temperature range (from 400 to 1000K), which illuminates the presence of two different acid sites owing to different NH3 absorption energies on the samples. The weak and strong acid sites were estimated from the desorption peak in the temperature range 500–720K and 870–1000K, respectively. The calculated results of the acidity sites intensity were shown in Table 1. The intensity order of acidity sites for catalysts was MFOH>NFO>NFOH>MFO for weak site and NFOH>NFO>MFOH>MFO for strong site. There was no significant rule for the weak acidity site, however, the nickel iron spinel and its hydroxyl oxides showed a higher intensity for the strong site. Importantly, the hydroxyl oxides of the iron spinel exhibited higher intensity than the calcined ones. The total intensity order of acidity sites for catalysts was NFOH>NFO>MFOH>MFO. Similarly, the emerging peaks in Fig. 2(B) represent for the basic sites. Both weakly and strongly adsorbed CO2 peaks were detected over a wide temperature range (from 400 to 1000K). The weak and strong basic sites in the temperature ranged in 350–620K and 850–1000K as derived from the CO2-TPD curves were also calculated and summarized in Table 1. The intensity order of basic sites for catalysts was MFOH>NFO>NFOH>MFO for weak site and NFOH>NFO>MFOH>MFO for strong site. The total intensity of basic sites was NFO>NFOH>MFOH>MFO, which was consistent with the concentration of the major acidity site. In this study, the point of zero charges (pHpzc) of the catalyst were also determined and shown in Table 1. The value of pHpzc reflects the surface acidity of the OH bond in metal oxides [31,32]. However, its order was not consistent with the results of TPD, indicating that the MeO bond of catalyst showed another role in the surface acid/basic site, except the OH bond. To further study the surface nature of the catalysts, samples were characterized by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) in Fig. 3 and Fourier transform-infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR) in Fig. 4 . The survey of XPS spectrums of all catalysts (Fig. S1) confirmed that catalysts contain Fe, O and C. Also, the element of Mn or Ni was detected in the corresponding catalysts. The presence of C in catalyst may be due to the absorbed CO2 that came from air on their surface. The surface charge was corrected by referencing the spectra to the CC state of the C 1s peak at a binding energy at 284.6eV. The peaks at 856.9 and 863.7eV in Fig. 3(A) could be assigned to the binding energies of Ni 2p3/2 and Ni 2p1/2, respectively, which were closed to the standard data for Ni2+ in both NFO and NFOH. Also, the presence of Mn 2p1/2 and Mn 2p3/2 were confirmed by the peaks of 653.9eV and 642.1eV in MFO or MFOH samples (Fig. 3(B)). The intensity of Ni or Mn in hydroxides was much lower than that in calcined oxides, because of the relative content of Ni or Mn is lower in the hydroxides. Generally, the O 1s region is fitted with peaks corresponding to O−2 from the MeO lattice (530.3±0.2eV), OH (531.5±0.2eV), and adsorbed H2O on the surface of oxides (533.7±0.2eV) [33–35]. From Fig. 3(C), no peak of adsorbed H2O was observed, suggesting a reliable storage under vacuum. The peaks of O−2 and OH were observed for all catalysts. But the intensities of them were significantly different. For hydroxides, the intensity of OH was higher than that of calcined oxides, especially for MFOH and MFO. The XPS spectrum of Fe 2p in Fig. 3(D) showed two distinct peaks at binding energies of 724.1eV as Fe 2p1/2 and 710.7eV as the Fe 2p3/2, which are the characteristic of Fe3+. Moreover, there was a satellite peak (718.6eV) existed for Fe 2p3/2 [36]. The FT-IR also showed surface functional groups of catalyst. The absorption peak with a wave number near 1633cm−1 was generally attributed to the bending vibration of OH (δOH), which was observed for all catalysts. This result of FT-IR was consistent with the deconvolution analysis of key species in XPS spectrum. The intensity of OH in hydroxides was higher than that in calcined oxides. FT-IR spectrum showing an adsorption band around 590cm−1 was observed for all samples, corresponded to the stretching vibration of the tetrahedral and octahedral sites of Fe3+ O, an evidence of spinal ferrite formation [37–39]. In MFOH and NFOH, the same peak exited but it exhibited a lower intensity than MFO and NFO, with the relative content of Fe being lower in hydroxides. Furthermore, the chemical shift of MnO and NiO stretching vibration in samples existed from 450 to 475cm−1 and 890–900cm−1, respectively. For the used samples, no significant change was observed for those key peaks, indicating the reutilization of catalysts will not deteriorate the surface functional groups, and the catalysts have good potentials to be recycled and reused in the catalytic ozonation process. Fig. 5 shows the field-dependent magnetization of the synthesized magnetic catalyst measured at 300K (±10kOe), where the magnetism was good for NFO and MFOH. The magnetism of MFO or NFOH was much lower than that of MFOH and NFO and therefore requires a larger magnetic field for their recycling. Based on this result, it was concluded that the degree of crystallization and particle size were not the limiting factors for the magnetism property. The interactions of MeFe and the types of metal elements might be the important factors [11,12]. The coercivities (H c) of NFO and NFOH were lower than those of MFO and MFOH, indicating the separation of NFO and NFOH from water by the magnetic fields was not limited by the direction of magnetic field. This was more significant for NFOH, a super-paramagnetic hydroxide, suggesting a good potential of NFOH in water treatment. After the catalysts were used in the catalytic ozonation process, the magnetization of MFO or MFOH changed significantly. This observation has never been reported before. The magnetization of MFO was increased after being used in catalytic ozonation. The opposite experimental phenomenon was observed for MFOH, because of the oxidation of Mn(II) to strengthen the interactions of MnFe. NFO and NFOH showed less change on the magnetization, indicating that they are suitable for used in applications that require catalyst recycling. 3.2 Performance and mineralization of PNT in catalytic ozonation The removal efficiency of PNT in catalytic ozonation using different catalysts was tested at an ozone dosage of 0.36mg/L, as shown in Fig. 6(A). The sole ozonation process (SOP) showed a pretty fast PNT decay, and over 95% of PNT was removed in 30min. This is because the ozone selectively attacked the activated aromatic rings of PNT. Also, the amino group (NH2) is an electron-donating group that activates the aromatic ring by increasing its electronic density [40–42], and this allows PNT to be oxidized easily. PNT has a higher trend for delocalizing electrons and exhibits an enhanced reactivity toward ozone. In terms of its reactivity to molecular ozone, the introduction of a catalyst developed the degradation performance slightly. Nevertheless, the involvement of four catalysts resulted in an additional rate of improvement of PNT decay at the descending order of NFOH, NFO, MFOH, and MFO. To evaluate the possible adsorption of PNT by the catalyst and the purging effect of the system, the ozone was replaced by oxygen and no PNT removal was observed. This suggested that the adsorption and purging of PNT was insignificant, and the additional PNT removal efficiency arose solely from catalytic oxidation. The mineralization in the SOP or in catalytic ozonation was also examined (Fig. 6(B)). The SOP mineralization efficiency was only 29.36% in 3h. In the presence of a catalyst, the mineralization increased to 60%, regardless of the catalyst selection. Most TOC removal was accomplished in 30min, which suggests that the degradation of PNT and its daughter compounds occurred mainly in the first 30min in either the SOP or in catalytic ozonation. The degradation of PNT and its mineralization probably occurs because of three mechanisms: (1) catalysts could increase the generation of reactive oxygen species (ROS) and these species can then react with PNT to form oxidized products or intermediates; (2) ozone is adsorbed by the catalyst and undergoes a surface reaction; and (3) the intermediates are adsorbed on the catalyst surface and undergo a subsurface reaction. This will be explained later. 3.3 Metal leaching in different catalytic reactions Metal leaching from the catalyst during oxidation was examined by ICP-AES with an acidification digestion pretreatment as shown in Fig. 7 , in which metal ion leaching is expressed as a percentage of the total metal in the catalyst. The maximum concentration of Fe, Mn and Ni leached was 0.034%, 0.0018% and 0.018%, respectively. Compared with the catalyst, the leaching of metal ions was insignificant. Two additional conclusions can be drawn from Fig. 7: (1) the concentration of dissolved metal would not cause any noticeable toxicity to human or aquatic animals/plants in the effluent after catalysis; and (2) the low level of metal in the homogeneous phase does not enhance the SOP efficiently as reported previously [43–48]. Therefore, the heterogeneous reaction dominated the catalytic ozonation process in this study. In addition, the metal leaching profiles also depend on the catalyst type. Catalysts that contained nickel showed a higher leaching concentration of Fe and Ni, and the leaching concentrations of Fe and Ni from NFO were higher than those from NFOH. For Fe, leaching emerged mainly in the early reaction stage, and then decreased because of adsorption by the catalyst or chemical precipitation. For Ni, the leaching concentration increased as the reaction proceeded. Catalysts that included manganese showed a lower leaching of metals. 3.4 Ozone concentration in different processes Since there was no adsorption of PNT on the catalysts, the interaction between the catalyst and ozone was likely the effective way responsible for the degradation and mineralization of PNT [49]. To test this hypothesis, dissolved ozone profiles in the aqueous phase ([O3]aq) without PNT were examined for different processes and these are shown in Fig. 8 . For sole ozone purging, after pre-ozonation, the dissolved ozone was generally maintained at a steady concentration, which was a balance of gas transfer process. When NFO or NFOH was added, the dissolved ozone concentration dropped significantly initially and then increased and returned to a steady concentration in 20min. This period of gas transfer balance was shorter than that in the process without catalyst. This phenomenon demonstrates that NFO or NFOH accelerated ozone decomposition in water at a similar rate. The catalytic ozone decomposition ability between NFO and NFOH were much closer. The addition of MFO or MFOH surprisingly resulted in a linear increase in dissolved ozone concentration in the first 10min, to reach a final [O3]aq at 10.08mg/L (MFO) or 11.80mg/L (MFOH). Apparently, the presence of MFO or MFOH accelerated the ozone transfer from gaseous to aqueous phase, instead of catalyzing ozone decomposition. This experimental phenomenon confirmed that the MFOH exhibited a stronger ability for the development of ozone mass transfer. Ozone shows properties of Brønsted basicity and may react with acidic metal oxide sites at the catalyst surface. [50]. The different reactions observed between ozone and catalysts in the above tests occur because of the different surface properties of nickel or manganese ferrite spinel. By cross checking the above observation and the surface acidity intensity (from the TPD test), it was found that the stronger surface acidity was good for catalytic ozone decomposition (in nickel ferrite spinel) and manganese ferrite spinel favored ozone gas transfer. 3.5 Hydroxyl radical generation yields in PNT degradation and mineralization Through identification of oxidant species, as discussed above, it was apparent that a heterogeneous catalyst surface is able to transfer ozone gas into the solution or produce •OH efficiently for different catalyst types, whereas no adsorption between the PNT and catalyst surface was observed. Therefore, in general, the PNT decomposition rate in the ozonation process can be modeled by a combination of two bimolecular reactions: direct ozonation and indirect catalytic oxidation by •OH as expressed by: (1) − d PNT d t = k O 3 ,PNT PNT O 3 + k • OH,PNT PNT • OH = k overall,PNT PNT where k O 3 and k • OH are the PNT reaction rate constants with molecular ozone and •OH, respectively. They can be calculated from the competitive kinetics as shown in Text S2, Table S1, and Fig. S2. Because of the lack of direct measurement methods for solution [•OH], the approach proposed by Elovitz and von Gunten [51] was used to determine the [•OH] during ozonation in batch and continuous experiments. The kinetics of PNT removal by ozonation/catalytic ozonation was investigated by assuming the ratio of [•OH] to [O3], R ct. This ratio is a constant during steady state ozonation, as given by Eq. (2), in which a higher R ct implies that a higher fraction of ozone is being converted to •OH (2) R ct,PNT = • OH O 3 By incorporating R ct into Eq. (1) and with integration, the removal of PNT can be formulated as: (3) ln [ PNT ] [ PNT ] 0 = − k O 3 ,PNT + k • OH,PNT R ct,PNT ∫ O 3 d t = − slope PNT ∫ O 3 d t Therefore, for a specific ozonation process R ct,PNT can be predicted from the [PNT] decay and the two rate constants k O 3 , PNT and k •OH,PNT. From Fig. 9 , the slopePNT and R ct,PNT in different processes were calculated as shown in Table 2 . An interesting observation is that slopePNT in MFO and MFOH catalytic ozonation is smaller than the k O 3 ,PNT , which indicates that the contribution of •OH for PNT degradation was insignificant in MFO or MFOH catalytic ozonation. The results are consistent with Fig. 8, in which no ozone decomposition (except enhanced ozone mass transfer) was observed in MFO or MFOH catalytic ozonation. The smaller slopePNT of MFOH than MFO also verifies the improved ability of the former in enhancing ozone mass transfer. The introduction of MFO or MFOH developed the ozone mass transfer, and indicated that molecular ozone rather than •OH oxidation dominated the degradation of PNT. The higher slopePNT for the NFO or NFOH processes over sole ozonation (and numerically larger value than for k O 3 ,PNT ), suggesting the presence of •OH oxidation in the sole ozonation, NFO and NFOH processes. The R ct,PNT in Table 2 confirm that NFOH is able to catalyze ozone decomposition more strongly than NFO. In the processes involving nickel ferrite (hydroxyl) oxide, •OH oxidation play a certain role in PNT degradation, because of the accelerated ozone decomposition by nickel ferrite (hydroxyl) oxide. In catalytic ozonation, the mineralization was examined by TOC decay, where the model compound profiles and their intermediates can be expressed by the following equation: (4) − r TOC = d TOC d t (5) − d TOC d t = k O 3 ,TOC TOC O 3 + k • OH,TOC TOC • OH Similar to R ct,PNT, R ct,TOC was defined in terms of TOC decay (6) R ct,TOC = • OH O 3 Eq. (5) can be transferred and rewritten as: (7) ln TOC TOC 0 = − k O 3 ,TOC + k • OH , TOC R ct,TOC ∫ O 3 d t = − slope TOC ∫ O 3 d t . The k O 3 ,TOC or k •OH,TOC are the TOC decay rate constants by molecular ozone or •OH, respectively. The determination of these decay constants is difficult; therefore, the variation of slopeTOC was used to examine the mineralization process. Higher slopeTOC resulted in a higher •OH contribution. From Fig. 10 , it can be seen that the reaction is divided into two stages. In general, nearly all PNT and the majority part of TOC were degraded in 30min in all the processes tested. In this stage, the •OH yields of mineralization by nickel ferrite catalysts were higher than those in SOP and manganese ferrite catalysts, which agreed with the observation in •OH yields of PNT degradation. Nickel ferrite catalysts catalyzed ozone to form •OH that oxidized PNT and its intermediates. Because the reaction constant between the intermediates and molecular ozone is lower than that of PNT [52], the contribution of •OH for mineralization was more apparent than that of the molecular ozone. No significant difference was observed between the hydroxyl and calcined oxides, which suggests that they showed a similar intermediate degradation performance. However, diversities in •OH mineralization yields were observed after 30min (i.e. stage 2), in which NFO showed a better •OH mineralization yield than NFOH. This was different from the PNT degradation. The •OH yields in the manganese ferrite catalytic system were higher than those in the SOP, which suggests that •OH contributed to intermediate degradation despite the fact that molecular ozone mass transfer development was achieved by manganese ferrite catalyst. The •OH did not arise from ozone decomposition, which will be shown later. Different reaction mechanisms exist for catalysts that involve nickel, and the catalyst with manganese exhibited a lower contribution of •OH in the degradation of intermediates. 3.6 Peroxide generation or decomposition in different processes H2O2 is a byproduct of the reaction of O3/•OH with olefinic products resulting from the breaking of the aromatic moiety of the initial substrate [53,54]; and it is also a ROS in catalytic ozonation [55]. From Fig. 11 , H2O2 was identified in all PNT degradation processes. In general, the [H2O2] increased first to a peak and then decreased because of consumption/degradation. The evolutions depended on the presence and type of catalyst. In SOP, the maximum yield of H2O2 that was generated from the degradation of PNT, was 0.066mM at 45min. This yield was the lowest of all reactions. The enhanced generation of H2O2 in the catalytic ozonation provides evidence for the development of PNT degradation. H2O2 yields in nickel ferrite catalytic ozonation were higher than those in the manganese ferrite reaction process. In addition, the yield of H2O2 in NFOH catalytic ozonation was higher than that in NFO; the yields of H2O2 in MFOH and MFO were at the same level. The maximum [H2O2] descended according to NFOH>NFO>MFOH>MFO>SOP, which is consistent with •OH generation in PNT degradation. The H2O2 decomposition in NFOH-driven catalytic ozonation (1.32×10−3 mM/min) was slightly slower than that in NFO (1.76×10−3 mM/min); while the rate in MFO (7.79×10−4 mM/min) was three times faster than in MFO (2.49×10−4 mM/min). PNT decay induces H2O2 formation, which is likely not self-decayed [56], but is decomposable by O3 [57,58] or a catalyst [59]. This H2O2 decomposition was confirmed from the results of Fig. 12 by dosing an initial [H2O2] of 1.0mM to each process without PNT. All processes followed pseudo first-order kinetics. Therefore, the evolution of H2O2 in catalytic ozonation of PNT can be expressed as: (8) PNT ⟶ ozone+catalyst k 1 H 2 O 2 ⟶ ozone+catalyst k 2 • OH From Fig. 12, it can be seen that manganese ferrite was better able to decompose H2O2 than nickel ferrite. Manganese ferrite has faster ozone mass transfer and H2O2 decomposition rates (i.e. higher k 2 in Eq. (8)), but did not lead to a better mineralization than NFO or NFOH. This is because the lower yield of H2O2 in the process (i.e. lower k 1 in Eq. (8)) limits the generation of •OH, and results in a lower PNT mineralization (Fig. 10). It is interesting to note that NFO has the lowest k2 but the highest TOC removal rate. This is likely because the slower (or well controlled) generation of •OH from H2O2 decomposition can reduce the reaction between •OH and H2O2 (which generate the much weaker •OOH radical). Therefore, the capability of NFO to maintain a low [•OH] in solution effectively improves the overall TOC removal compared with other catalysts. 3.7 Intermediates adsorption/degradation over catalyst surface A sequential test was performed to understand the role of catalyst in degradation PNT and its daughter compounds. First, a solution of PNT was ozonized for 1h to generate intermediates; then oxygen was bubbled into the solution for 10min to remove the remaining dissolved ozone. The catalyst was then introduced to the solution and mixed for 1h to evaluate the adsorption of intermediates by the catalysts. Finally, the performance of catalyst in the removal of intermediates was examined by resuming the supply of ozone for 1h. Results were shown in Fig. 13 , which was different from results in Fig. 6(B) in a continuous mode. Based on the above discussion, the reaction system was divided into: (1) the •OH dominating reaction involved in nickel ferrite system; (2) molecule ozone dominating reaction involved in manganese ferrite system. From Fig. 13, the final TOC removal efficiency in NFOH catalytic ozonation was higher than that in NFO, which was opposite to the result of Fig. 6. The higher intermediate adsorption capacity on the NFOH surface was good effective for degradation by •OH, for no desorption was observed for this kind catalyst. This was not observed in the manganese ferrite catalytic ozonation reaction. Manganese ferrite showed adsorption/desorption of the intermediate; while no desorption was observed for the nickel ferrite. Therefore, the possible desorption of PNT/intermediates out of the manganese ferrite surface is another reason for their lower mineralization performance. 4 Conclusion Catalysts MnFe2O4 and NiFe2O4 were synthesized by co-precipitation- combustion as a simple and affordable method, and used for catalytic ozonation in water treatment. It was found that their precursors, MnFe2(OH)8 (MFOH) and NiFe2(OH)8 (NFOH), showed certain magnetic properties and gave excellent catalytic activity to enhance ozonation. A heterogeneous reaction dominated the catalytic processes, and all catalysts showed low metal leaching, so the effluent is safe for disposal. The variation of catalyst magnetization after repeated usages was generally insignificant, suggesting a long catalyst life-cycle. The structure and surface of catalyst, performance and mineralization on PNT degradation, and reactive oxygen species (ROS) identification were investigated systematically. Furthermore, the fate of the intermediates on the surface of spinel oxides showed a different influence from the catalytic ozonation process. In general, two distinct reaction mechanisms were observed. One was the improvement of ozone transfer into the solution, and the other was the formation of a critical intermediate (H2O2) that was generated in the presence of ozone and PNT. Therefore the hydroxyl radical (•OH) was generated catalytically by the decomposition of H2O2, which makes the mineralization of PNT and its intermediates possible. coredata.dc:description: In this study, a systematic investigation on the degradation of phenacetin (PNT) by magnetic spinel ferrite (including MnFe2O4 and NiFe2O4) via catalytic ozonation was carried out. The structural and surface property of the catalyst, the performance and mineralization during PNT degradation, and •OH/H2O2 identification were studied. The precursors of the catalyst, i.e. MnFe2(OH)8 and NiFe2(OH)8, showed certain magnetic properties and a superior catalytic activity for ozonation enhancement than spinel ferrites. Spinel ferrites containing manganese initiate an ozone mass transfer into the solution, where the critical intermediate (H2O2) is generated. The manganese ferrite spinel triggers H2O2 decomposition in the presence of ozone and generates •OH for the mineralization of PNT and its intermediates. Spinel ferrites involved nickel catalyzed ozone decomposition and generate H2O2 and •OH. All catalysts showed a weak heavy metal leaching, which suggests that the heterogeneous reaction dominates the catalytic reaction and the resultant effluent is safe for the aqueous environment. The magnetic variation of catalysts involving nickel is insignificant, suggesting that the catalyst can be reused many times. The fate of the intermediates on spinel oxides surface influenced for the catalytic ozonation process differently.
coredata.dc:title: Heterogeneous catalytic ozonation of phenacetin in water using magnetic spinel ferrite as catalyst: Comparison of surface property and efficiency
